channel.title: World
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: British Ambassador To U.S. Says Scottish Vote Is 'Decisive'
item.description: Robert Siegel talks with Peter Westmacott, British Ambassador to the U.S., about Scotland's unsuccessful vote for independence and what changes may result throughout the U.K. because of the campaign.
item.content:encoded:
Robert Siegel talks with Peter Westmacott, British Ambassador to the U.S., about Scotland's unsuccessful vote for independence and what changes may result throughout the U.K. because of the campaign.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Iran Nuclear Talks Have A Different Tone This Time Around
item.description: In New York on Friday, Iran and six world powers sat down for the latest talks aimed at limiting Iran's nuclear program in exchange for sanctions relief.
item.content:encoded:
In New York on Friday, Iran and six world powers sat down for the latest talks aimed at limiting Iran's nuclear program in exchange for sanctions relief.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Peter Kenyon

item.title: United Kingdom Remains Intact But Not Unchanged
item.description: The independence referendum in Scotland has shaken, but not broken, the ties between the countries in the United Kingdom. Many politicians and observers believe that the relationship between Scotland and England has now permanently changed.
item.content:encoded:
The independence referendum in Scotland has shaken, but not broken, the ties between the countries in the United Kingdom. Many politicians and observers believe that the relationship between Scotland and England has now permanently changed.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Ari Shapiro

item.title: With IPO, Alibaba Hopes To Compete In The West
item.description: Shares of Chinese Internet giant Alibaba started trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday. The company raised more than $20 billion with its initial public offering, shattering a U.S. record set by Visa in 2008.
item.content:encoded:
Shares of Chinese Internet giant Alibaba started trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday. The company raised more than $20 billion with its initial public offering, shattering a U.S. record set by Visa in 2008.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Jim Zarroli

item.title: In Liberia, Ebola Hygiene Kits May Send The Wrong Message
item.description: The hygiene kits include surgical gloves, soap and other basic protective gear. Some experts worry that the kits send the message that families are supposed to care for sick relatives at home.
item.content:encoded:
The hygiene kits include surgical gloves, soap and other basic protective gear. Some experts worry that the kits send the message that families are supposed to care for sick relatives at home.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Nurith Aizenman

item.title: Sierra Leone On Lockdown Over Ebola
item.description: The government is sending thousands of volunteers door-to-door, trying to find people who've had contact with people sick with Ebola, as well as hidden pockets of the disease.
item.content:encoded:
The government is sending thousands of volunteers door-to-door, trying to find people who've had contact with people sick with Ebola, as well as hidden pockets of the disease.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Anders Kelto

item.title: What Does 'Boots On The Ground' Really Mean?
item.description: The Obama administration says that American advisers sent to Iraq will not have a combat mission. But military experts say it's almost impossible to draw a line between combat and non-combat roles.
item.content:encoded:
The Obama administration says that American advisers sent to Iraq will not have a combat mission. But military experts say it's almost impossible to draw a line between combat and non-combat roles.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Tom Bowman

item.title: 'Braveheart' Writer 'Heartbroken' Over Scottish Referendum
item.description: Braveheart, written by Randall Wallace, inspired a generation in Scotland. So much so that the core of supporters of Scottish independence have been referred to as the "Braveheart Generation."
item.content:encoded:
Braveheart, written by Randall Wallace, inspired a generation in Scotland. So much so that the core of supporters of Scottish independence have been referred to as the "Braveheart Generation."

» E-Mail This

item.title: To Foil Russia's Food Ban, Imported Ingredients Go Incognito
item.description: Russia's ban on imported foods hasn't stopped its trendiest restaurants from sourcing top-quality ingredients like Italian cheese and Norwegian fish. How? Just slap on a "made in Belarus" label.
item.content:encoded:
Russia's ban on imported foods hasn't stopped its trendiest restaurants from sourcing top-quality ingredients like Italian cheese and Norwegian fish. How? Just slap on a "made in Belarus" label.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Corey Flintoff

item.title: His Camera Takes Us To The World 'We Must Preserve'
item.description: In the new exhibit "Genesis," the noted photographer Sebastiao Salgado shares his vision of "a kind of state of humanity of the planet," from Amazon tribes to frozen Siberia.
item.content:encoded:
In the new exhibit "Genesis," the noted photographer Sebastiao Salgado shares his vision of "a kind of state of humanity of the planet," from Amazon tribes to frozen Siberia.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Rena Silverman

item.title: Iconic Pabst Beer Brands Sold To Russian Company
item.description: Pabst Brewing Co., with its famous Blue Ribbon, Old Milwaukee and Schlitz labels, is being acquired by Russian brewer Oasis Beverages for an undisclosed sum.
item.content:encoded:
Pabst Brewing Co., with its famous Blue Ribbon, Old Milwaukee and Schlitz labels, is being acquired by Russian brewer Oasis Beverages for an undisclosed sum.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: LOOK: U.K. Front Pages On Scotland's 'No' Vote
item.description: From "It's No!" to "No Thanks," British newspapers devoted their front pages to news that voters in Scotland rejected independence by a 55 percent-to-45 percent margin.
item.content:encoded:
From "It's No!" to "No Thanks," British newspapers devoted their front pages to news that voters in Scotland rejected independence by a 55 percent-to-45 percent margin.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Krishnadev Calamur

item.title: Women Can't Make Sushi, And Other Fishy Myths, Busted
item.description: Sushi is supposed to be eaten at room temperature and right after it's made. So why are we buying out of the cold case at the supermarket? And where are all the female sushi chefs?
item.content:encoded:
Sushi is supposed to be eaten at room temperature and right after it's made. So why are we buying out of the cold case at the supermarket? And where are all the female sushi chefs?

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: April Fulton and Allison Aubrey

item.title: India's Modi Calls Al-Qaida's Plans For His Country 'Delusional'
item.description: The Indian prime minister, in an interview, called his country's Muslims patriots. The remarks are his most forthcoming on India's Muslims, many of whom doubted his commitment to religious minorities.
item.content:encoded:
The Indian prime minister, in an interview, called his country's Muslims patriots. The remarks are his most forthcoming on India's Muslims, many of whom doubted his commitment to religious minorities.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Julie McCarthy

item.title: Iran's 'Happy' Dancers Receive Suspended Sentences
item.description: Seven young Iranians were arrested in May for producing their own version of the Pharrell Williams song "Happy." Iranian authorities said the video, which went viral, offended public morals.
item.content:encoded:
Seven young Iranians were arrested in May for producing their own version of the Pharrell Williams song "Happy." Iranian authorities said the video, which went viral, offended public morals.
